stem: The nurse is reviewing the arterial blood gas (ABG) results for four clients. Based on the documented lab values in the EHR, match each set of values to the correct acid-base imbalance.

tabs.title: Clinical Scenarios
tabs.content:
Client 1: History of COPD, currently exhibiting increased work of breathing.
Client 2: History of bulimia; reports 4 days of persistent vomiting.
Client 3: Client with Type 1 Diabetes, arriving with fruity-smelling breath and Kussmaul respirations.
Client 4: Arrived in the ED with a severe panic attack; respiratory rate is 42/min.

rationale.correct: Client 1 (r1) has a low pH and high PaCO2, indicating Respiratory Acidosis (COPD). Client 2 (r2) has a high pH and high HCO3, indicating Metabolic Alkalosis (Vomiting). Client 3 (r3) has a low pH and low HCO3, indicating Metabolic Acidosis (DKA). Client 4 (r4) has a high pH and low PaCO2, indicating Respiratory Alkalosis (Hyperventilation).
clinicalPearls: Respiratory = Opposite (pH Down, CO2 Up = Acidosis).
Metabolic = Equal (pH Up, HCO3 Up = Alkalosis).
Kussmaul respirations in DKA are a compensatory mechanism to blow off CO2 and correct metabolic acidosis.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that all respiratory issues always lead to acidosis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the rate. Hyperventilation (Anxiety/Panic) blows off CO2, leading to alkalosis, while hypoventilation (COPD/Narcotics) retains CO2, leading to acidosis.
